The radiant ruler of the year</br>At length his wintry goal attains,</br>Soon to reverse the long career,</br>And Northward bend his golden reins.</br>Prone on POTOSI'S haughty brow</br>His fiery streams incessant flow,</br>Ripening the silver's ductile stores;</br>While, in the caven's horrid shade,</br>The panting Indian hides his head,</br>And oft th' approach of eve explores.

But lo, on this deserted coast</br>How faint the light!  how thick the air!</br>Lo, arm'd with whilwind, hail and frost,</br>Fierce winter desolates the year,</br>The fields resign their chearful bloom;</br>No more the breezes waft perfume,</br>No more the warbling waters roll:</br>Desarts of snow fatigue the eye,</br>Black storms involve the louring sky,</br>And gloomy damps oppress the soul.

Now thro' the town promiscuous throngs</br>Urge the warm bowl and ruddy fire;</br>Harmonious dances, festive songs,</br>To charm the midnight hours conspire.</br>While mute and shrinking with her fears,</br>Each blast the cottage-matron hears</br>As o'er the hearth she sits alone:</br>At morn her bridegroom went abroad,</br>The night is dark and deep the road;</br>She sighs and wishes him at home.

But thou, my lyre, awake, arise,</br>And hail the sun's remotest ray;</br>Now, now  he climbs the Northern skies,</br>To-morrow nearer than to-day.</br>Then louder howl the stormy waste,</br>Be land and ocean worse defac'd,</br>Yet brighter hours are on the wing;</br>And fancy thro' the wintry glooms,</br>All fresh with dews and opening blooms,</br>Already hails th' emerging spring.

O fountain of the golden day!</br>Could mortal vows but urge thy speed,</br>How soon before thy vernal ray</br>Should each unkindly damp recede!</br>How soon each hov'ring tempest fly,</br>That now fermenting loads the sky,</br>Prompt on our heads to burst amain,</br>To rend the forest from the steep,</br>Or thund'ring o'er the Baltic deep</br>To whelm the merchant's hopes of gain!

But let not man's unequal views</br>Presume on nature and her laws;</br>'Tis his with grateful joy to use</br>Th' indulgence of the sov'reign cause;</br>Secure that health and beauty springs</br>Thro' this majestic frame of things</br>Beyond what he can reach to know,</br>And that heav'n's all-subduing will,</br>With good the progeny of ill,</br>Attempers every state below.

How pleasing wears the wintry night,</br>Spent with the old illustrious dead!</br>While, by the taper's trembling light,</br>I seem those awful courts to tread</br>Where chiefs and legislators lie,</br>Whose triumphs move before my eye</br>With every laurel fresh-display'd;</br>While charm'd I taste th' Ionian song,</br>Or bend to PLATO'S godlike tongue</br>Resounding thro' the olive-shade.

But if the gay, well-natur'd friend</br>Bids leave the studious page awhile,</br>Then easier joys the soul unbend</br>And teach the brow a softer smile;</br>Then while the genial glass is paid</br>By each to her, that fairest maid,</br>Whose radiant eyes his hopes obey,</br>What lucky vows his bosom warm!</br>While absence heightens every charm,</br>And love invokes returning MAY.

MAY!  thou delight of heav'n and earth,</br>When will thy happy morn arise?</br>When the dear place which gave her birth</br>Restore LUCINDA to my eyes?</br>There while she walks the wonted grove,</br>The seat of music and of love,</br>Bright as the ONE primaeval fair,</br>Thither, ye silver-sounding lyres,</br>Thither, gay smiles and young desires,</br>Chast hope and mutual faith repair.

And if believing love can tread</br>The wonted softness in her eye,</br>Then shall my fears, O charming maid,</br>And every pain of absence die:</br>Then ofter to thy name attun'd,</br>And rising to diviner sound,</br>I'll wake the free HORATIAN song:</br>Old TYNE shall listen to my tale,</br>And ECHO, down the bord'ring vale,</br>The liquid melody prolong.</br>
